choices.text: Efferent arteriole mild constriction- GFR increased

questions.text: Which of the following is correctly matched?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Efferent arteriole mild constriction- GFR increased.

questions.text: Given below is the myogram of a single muscle twitch. What is the tetanizing frequency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

40-49 Hz

Tetanizing frequency is 1/contraction period (seconds).

Here the contraction period is 22milliseconds or 22/1000 second.

Tetanizing frequency will, therefore, be 1000/22 per second or 40- 49 Hz.

questions.text: In a person on a high potassium diet, which part of the nephron would be expected to secrete the most potassium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Collecting tubule

Potassium secretion occurs in the late DCT and collecting tubules. A high potassium diet will increase the aldosterone levels which in turn increases secretion from the late DCT and CT.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct formula for calculation of ejection fraction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

EF = EDV – ESV/ EDV

EF = Stroke volume / End diastolic volume
SV = EDV – ESV
So, EF = EDV – ESV/ EDV
Normal ejection fraction is 0.55- 0.65 or 55- 65%.

choices.text: Descending thin segment of loop of henle
Thick ascending limb of loop of henle

questions.text: Which nephron segment is the primary site of magnesium reabsorption in normal conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Thick ascending limb of loop of henle

The primary site of magnesium reabsorption is the TAL, where 65% of the filtered magnesium is reabsorbed. The PCT normally reabsorbs only about 25% of the filtered magnesium, and the DCT and CT reabsorb less than 5%.

questions.text: Which of the following waves of JVP occurs in the isovolumetric contraction phase?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

C wave

“a wave” of JVP is due to atrial contraction, which is responsible for the second rapid filling phase. “c wave” is due to bulging of the closed tricuspid valve into the RA during isovolumetric contraction. “x descent” is due to downward pull of the closed TV into the RV during the ejection phase. “v wave” is due to venous filling of the RA just before opening of the tricuspid valve. “y descent” is due to flow of blood from the RA into the RV during the first rapid filling phase.

questions.text: At which point on the nerve action potential shown in the figure given below is the membrane closest to the equilibrium potential for potassium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

point C

When a stimulus is given to a nerve it causes opening of voltage gated sodium channels which increases the membrane permeability for sodium. Sodium entry into the cell causes the cell to depolarize. The potential reaches +30mV (point A), which is closest to the equilibrium potential for sodium (+60mV). This is followed by repolarization which is due to opening of voltage gated potassium channels. At point C the RMP is more negative due to slower closure of voltage gated potassium channels which is closest to the equilibrium potential for potassium (-90mV).

questions.text: While playing football, the ball hits a 12-year old boy on his shin with considerable force. He sits on the ground and starts rubbing the area to reduce the pain. Inhibition of pain signals by tactile stimulation of the skin is mediated by which type of afferent neurons from the mechanoreceptors.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Aβ By rubbing the area touch receptors are stimulated. Touch sensation carried by type Aβ fibres causes a pre-synaptic inhibition of the pain pathway in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord (Gate control theory of Melzac and Wall).

choices.text: Secretion is stimulated by somatostatin and inhibited by ghrelin
It has a long half life
It stimulates production of IGF-1 by the liver

questions.text: A 33-year-old national level basketball player takes human growth hormone to increase his performance. Which of the following best describes human growth hormone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

It stimulates production of IGF-1 by the liver GH exerts many of its effects on growth and metabolism by stimulating the production and release of somatomedins from the liver, cartilage and other tissues. The principal somatomedin in humans is somatomedin-C (also k/a IGF-1). GH release is stimulated by GHRH from the hypothalamus and ghrelin from the stomach. GH is not bound to a protein and therefore, has a short half-life. GH increases protein synthesis and is therefore, anabolic.

questions.text: Tubular concentration of which of the following substances will be the highest at the end of PCT?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

PAH

PAH is freely filtered and completely secreted in the PCT. Its tubular fluid concentration will therefore, be the highest at the end of PCT.

questions.text: All except the following are component of juxta glomerular apparatus (JGA)-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Loop of Henle.

questions.text: Myogenic autoregulation of renal plasma flow occurs due to-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Myogenic autoregulation is due to opening of stretch sensitive calcium channels.

choices.text: Sensory fibre from Golgi tendon organ

questions.text: Least conduction velocity is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Preganglionic autonomic fibres are type B. All others are type A fibres. Type B has least conduction velocity.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman with type 2 DM is being monitored for her renal glucose handling. During the monitoring, clinician observed that glucose appeared in her urine even at low plasma glucose concentrations. What is the most likely reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The splay effect describes the phenomenon when glucose starts to appear in urine before reaching expected transport maximum. This occurs due to heterogenicity of nephrons.

choices.text: Funny channels open during depolarization and responsible for Ca2+ influx
Funny channels close upon hyperpolarization and restrict Na+ influx
Funny channels open upon hyperpolarization, allowing influx of both Na+ & Ca2+
Funny channels open upon hyperpolarization, allowing influx of both Na+ & K+

questions.text: All except the following is false about the role of  funny sodium channels in pacemaker potential-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Funny channels open upon hyperpolarization, allowing influx of both Na+ & K+

choices.text: Parallel and opposite flow of fluids
Active transport of solutes across all segments

questions.text: All except the following are prerequisites for a functional counter current mechanism in the body-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

While active transport is essential in some segments such as TAL of LOH it is not required across all segments.

choices.text: Increased heart rate through parasympathetic withdrawal
Increased heart rate through sympathetic stimulation
Increased heart rate through parasympathetic stimulation
Increased stroke volume via Frank Starling Mechanism

questions.text: A 70-year-old heart transplant patient reports that he has been engaging in moderate exercise for about 45 minutes daily. Despite lacking autonomic innervation to his heart, he notices an increase in his stamina and ability to exercise over time. Given the patient’s condition, what physiological mechanism is responsible for increase in his cardiac output during exercise?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Frank starling mechanism allows the heart to increase cardiac output by enhancing SV in response to increased venous return. While parasympathetic withdrawal can lead to slight increase in HR but is not the primary mechanism by which cardiac output is increased in these heart transplant patients during exercise.

choices.text: Capillaries are more prone to rupture due to high wall tension
Increased flow velocity in narrow vessels increases lateral pressure
The total energy in a tube or blood vessel remains constant
Dilated hearts have to work harder due to increased wall tension

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the LaPlace law?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Dilated hearts have to work harder due to increased wall tension.  Capillaries have low tension in vessel wall so resistant to rupture. Increased flow velocity in narrow vessels decreases lateral pressure.

questions.text: A 57-year-old diabetic woman is being treated with a medication that inhibits the reabsorption of glucose by the kidneys. What is the likely transporter inhibited by this medication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

SGLT-2.

questions.text: A patient undergoing coronary angioplasty for MI suddenly develops hypotension, bradycardia & apnoea. Which of the following reflexes is most likely mediated by chemo sensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Reperfusion in MI activates chemo sensitive vagal fibres in the cardio pulmonary region causing Bezold Jarisch reflex.

questions.text: Which of the following neurotransmitter is incorrectly matched with its site of production?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Main source of Ach is Nucleus basalis of Meynert.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the precision of synaptic connection between the neurons. Which of the following key proteins help in precise targeting of synaptic connections to ensure accurate neuronal communication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Synaptic specificity refers to precise targeting of neurons to form connections with the other appropriate neurons. It is maintained by neurexins (presynaptic adhesion molecules) and neuroligins (on post synaptic membrane).

choices.text: The stroke volume is higher than normal suggesting improved cardiac output
The cardiac output is higher than normal
The cardiac output can we calculated from the given from the given values
The ejection fraction of the patient is below the normal range indicating reduce ventricular function

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient undergoes cardiac evaluation & the following values are obtained- EDV= 130 mL and the ejection fraction of 45%.  Which of the following best describes the patient's cardiac parameters?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

An ejection fraction off 45% is below the normal range (50-70%) which may suggest reduced ventricular function or potential heart failure.

choices.text: S1 occurs immediately after end of T wave
S1 begins during the ST segment and ends before the T wave
S1 is heard simultaneously at the peak of R wave in all the leads
S1 starts 0.02- 0.04s after the onset of QRS complex

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding timing and correlation of S1 with the ECG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

S1 typically start 0.02 to 0.04 s after the onset of QRS complex. This slight delay represents the time between the electrical activation of the ventricles and mechanical closure of AV valves which produces S 1.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with complains of difficulty in maintaining posture. Upon examination, the physician notices that the patient has diminished reflexes. Which of the following nerve fibres is responsible for transmitting information about the velocity and length of muscle stretch from the muscle spindle to the spinal cord?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Type -Ia fibres are afferents from both nuclear bag dynamic and static fibers. These are responsible for transmitting information about the velocity and length of muscle stretch from the muscle spindle to spinal cord.

choices.text: The pathway can localize precise location of pain
The pathway can localize precise location of temperature
The pathway can localize precise location of pain to exact muscle groups involved in movements
The pathway localizes pain only to major body parts, such as an arm or leg due to its diffuse connectivity

questions.text: Which of the following statement correctly describes the localization capability of the paleospinothalamic pain pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Slow pain can usually be localized only to major body parts, such as an arm or leg, but not to a specific point on the arm or leg. This is due to the multi-synaptic & diffuse connectivity of the pain pathway.

questions.text: A new mother calls the paediatrician because she is concerned that her infant defecates after meal. Which of the following is the cause of these normal bowel movements in newborns?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

gastrocolic reflex Distension of the stomach initiates contraction of the rectum and often, a desire to defecate. This response is called the gastrocolic reflex. This response leads to defecation after meals in infants and children.

questions.text: The phases of the cardiac action potential are represented by the lettered points on the diagram below. At which point on the action potential is the membrane potential most dependent on calcium permeability?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Point C
The depolarization phase of the cardiac action potential is due to opening of voltage gated sodium channels and plateau phase is due to potassium efflux and a calcium influx through slow calcium channels (also k/a slow sodium- calcium channels).

questions.text: Which type of mechanoreceptor is primarily responsible for two- point discrimination and ability to read braille by detecting fine touch and texture details on the finger tips?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Merkel disks are often grouped together in a receptor organ called touch domes, which project upward against the underside of the epithelium of the skin. This upward projection causes the epithelium to protrude forming a dome (Iggo dome receptor).

choices.text: The caudate nucleus primarily uses glutamate as its neurotransmitter
The globus pallidus externus (GPe) exerts an excitatory influence on thalamus
The substantia nigra pars reticulata (SNpr) inhibits the thalamus using dopamine
The subthalamic nucleus uses glutamate to excite the globus pallidus internus (GPi)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the basal ganglia and their associated neurotransmitters is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The subthalamic nucleus uses glutamate to excite the globus pallidus internus (GPi)

questions.text: The cardiovascular responses to isotonic exercise include an increase in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

stroke volume
During exercise, sympathetic stimulation of the heart increases the contractility and thus, the stroke volume. A decrease in venous compliance, caused by sympathetic stimulation, increases the venous return to the heart, which also increases stroke volume by a Frank- Starling mechanism. The increased stroke volume, coupled with an increase in heart rate, causes an increase in cardiac output. Systemic arterial pressure also increases in response to the increase in cardiac output. Exercise causes release of local metabolites in muscles which leads to local vasodilation. This in turn decreases the total peripheral resistance resulting in a decrease in DBP. The pulmonary blood vessels also undergo a passive dilatation as more blood flows into the pulmonary circulation. As a result, pulmonary vascular resistance decreases.

choices.text: The vestibulo-cerebellar serves as the pathway for climbing fibres
Climbing fibres use aspartate to provide excitatory input to Purkinje cells
Mossy fibres use glutamate to provide excitatory signals to Granule cells
Climbing fibres are the terminal endings of the olivocerebellar tract

questions.text: Which of the following statements about climbing & mossy fibres are correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Climbing & mossy fibres are the main afferent pathways that provide the excitatory input to the cerebellar cortex. Climbing fibres use aspartate & Mossy fibres use glutamate to provide excitatory input to Purkinje cells.

questions.text: All of the following cause heterometric regulation of cardiac output except-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

When cardiac output is regulated by changes in cardiac muscle fiber length, this is referred to as heterometric regulation. Conversely, changes in contractility independent of length is called homometric regulation of cardiac output.

choices.text: Cingulate gyrus- controls heart rate, blood pressure
Mamillary body- responsible for controlling recent memories of the brain
Para hippocampal gyrus- spatial memory (memory of 3-dimensional space)

questions.text: Which of the following parts of the Papez circuit is incorrectly matched with their function?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hippocampus- conversion of short-term memory to long term memory.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a persistent dry cough and dyspnoea. CT scan of the chest shows localized airway obstruction at the level of the respiratory bronchioles. Which generation (Wiebel’s classification) is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Respiratory bronchioles are from generations 17-19.

choices.text: At the base –PO2 is lowest and PCO2 is highest
At the apex- PO2 is lowest and PCO2 is highest
At the middle –PO2 is lowest and PCO2 is highest
At the base- PO2 is highest and PCO2 is lowest

questions.text: What are the expected partial pressures of oxygen and carbon dioxide at the apex, middle and basal portions of the lungs in a person in erect posture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

at the base –PO2 is lowest and PCO2 is highest as V/Q ratio is minimum at the base and maximum at the apex.

questions.text: Which of the following formulas gives the oxygen extraction ratio of a substance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Oxygen extraction ratio is defined as the ratio of oxygen consumption/ oxygen supply. Normally, it is around 25% but can rise to 50-80% during exercise.

questions.text: All of the following would be expected to increase the mean systemic filling pressure except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increased venous compliance
Mean systemic filling pressure or Psf is the pressure measured everywhere in the systemic circulation after blood flow has been stopped by clamping the great vessels. Without blood flow pressures everywhere in the systemic circulation become equal and this equilibrated pressure level is the mean systemic filling pressure. Normal Psf is 7 mm Hg. Psf is the major pressure affecting venous return. The two main determinants of Psf are (i) blood volume, and (ii) sympathetic stimulation. 
Mean systemic filling pressure will increase with increase in blood volume. Increased sympathetic discharge will cause a decrease in venous compliance and increase the mean systemic filling pressure increasing the venous return. Therefore, a decreased and not an increased venous compliance will increase the mean systemic filling pressure. Parasympathetic stimulation has no effect on mean systemic filling pressure.

choices.text: Chloride shift causing swelling of red blood cells
Lower plasma volume in venous blood
Greater carbon dioxide content in venous blood

questions.text: Which of the following contributes to higher haematocrit in venous blood?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

A small amount of blood from arterial blood returns into circulation via lymphatics reducing plasma volume in veins, venous blood has higher CO2 content which results in increased HCO3- formation in RBCs.

choices.text: O2 uptake into pulmonary capillaries is dependent on diffusion properties of membrane
O2 uptake into pulmonary capillaries is dependent on temperature
O2 uptake into pulmonary capillaries is dependent on blood flowing through it

questions.text: Oxygen is classified as perfusion limited gas. What does this imply about its diffusion properties?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

O2 uptake into pulmonary capillaries is dependent on blood flowing through it.

questions.text: Which of the following intestinal cells have high zinc concentration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Paneth cells – specialized immune cells ( rich in zinc) at the bottom of the intestinal crypts of Lieberkühn in small intestine secrete antimicrobial peptides such as defensins and lysozymes. Enterocytes are absorptive cells lining the intestinal villi. Goblet cells are mucus secreting cells present throughout the intestines. Enteroendocrine cells are scattered throughout GIT and produce hormines like serotonin, gastrin and CCK.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the effects of CCK on intestinal motility?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CCK is the major stimulus for gall bladder emptying and pancreatic enzyme secretion, thus it causes relaxation of sphincter of Oddi.

questions.text: Which group of neurons is involved in controlling forceful expiration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

VRG contains both I & E neurons, they are only required when more ventilation is needed.

choices.text: Decrease in respiratory rate over time

questions.text: What primary physiological change sustains increased ventilation over several days of high-altitude exposure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Kidneys excrete HCO3- / alkali to counteract the levels of elevated pH caused by increased rate & depth of ventilation. This helps to normalize the blood pH and allows for sustained increase in ventilation over several days.

questions.text: A patient presents in the emergency department with a history of progressive respiratory distress. An arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis is obtained while the patient is breathing room air shows the following: PaO2 = 65mm Hg, SaO2 = 0.90, PaCO2 = 50mm Hg, pH = 7.30. The patient's temperature is 37 degrees C, barometric pressure is 760 mm Hg, Water vapor pressure at body temperature is 47 mmHg and respiratory quotient is 0.8. What is the patient's alveolar-arterial oxygen tension gradient; P(A-a)O2?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

To solve this we first need to determine the PAO2. This is done by using the alveolar gas equation.
PAO2  = [(PB – PH2O) X fractional concentration of O2] – (PACO2/RQ)
= [(760 – 47) X 21/100] – (50/0.8)
= 713 X 0.21 – 62.5
= 149.73 – 62.5
= 87.23 mm Hg
Since the arterial O2 has been given as 65mm Hg, the A-a O2 gradient is 87 -65 = 22 mm Hg.

questions.text: Which of the following substances has the highest TF/P ratios at the end of the PCT?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

PAH

PAH is freely filtered and completely secreted in the PCT. Its tubular fluid concentration will therefore, be the highest at the end of PCT.

questions.text: Shown below is the response of a hormone to a meal and insulin-induced hypoglycemia. The hormone is most likely to be which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The most potent stimulus for secretion of growth hormone is fasting, starvation or hypoglycemia.

questions.text: Each molecule of troponin C can bind how many calcium ions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

4

Each molecule of troponin-C can bind strongly with up to 4 calcium ions.

questions.text: Which of the following is greater in afterloaded muscle contractions as compared to preloaded muscle contractions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Latent period.
•    Preload is the load placed on a muscle before the muscle contracts. 
•    It serves to stretch the muscle sarcomeres, thus producing a passive tension across the muscle.
•    This passive tension increases muscle contraction in two ways:
    (i) It adds an elastic recoil force to the muscle during its contraction;
    (ii) It stretches the muscle to its resting length, producing the optimum     length-tension relationship for active force generation. 
•    In real life situations, it is a common practice to pre-stretch a muscle using antagonist muscles. 
•    After load is an opposing force which the muscle encounters immediately after it starts contracting. It is a force that a muscle must overcome before an observable shortening of the muscle can occur.
•    The contraction and work done of an after-loaded muscle is comparatively lesser.

questions.text: Which of the following are best suited to measure the intracellular fluid volume?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Heavy water and inulin
Measurement of ICF is indirect. ICF = TBW – ECF. Heavy water is most used for measurement of total body eater and Inulin is the most accurate for measurement of ECF volume. A combination of heavy water and inulin is best suited for measurement of ICF. Radioactive sodium is used for ECF measurement. 
Radioactive iodine labelled albumin is used for measurement of plasma volume.

questions.text: ECF is what percentage of the TBW in (Ls) in a man weighing 60 kg?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

ECF is 12L out of TBW which is 36 Ls. So, 12/36 x 100= 33%.

questions.text: Baroreceptor is which type of feedback?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Increase in blood pressure stimulates the baroreceptors which in turn decreases sympathetic outflow lowering the blood pressure. Fall in bp decreases baroreceptor stimulation which in turn increases sympathetic outflow increasing the blood pressure. In both cases there is a reversal of the initiating stimulus. Reversal of the initiating stimulus is a characteristic feature of negative feedback.

questions.text: If alveolar surface area is decreased by 50% and pulmonary fibrosis leads to doubling of diffusion distance, how will the diffusion of O2 be affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

decreases by 75%
Diffusion of gases across the respiratory membrane follows the Fick’s law of diffusion. 
Net transport 
= - (diffusion coefficient) (surface area) (concentration gradient)/ (thickness of membrane)
Transport is directly proportional to surface area and inverse to the thickness of membrane. If the surface area is decreased to half and thickness of membrane is doubled, transport decreases to one-fourth or in other words, decreases by 75%.

choices.text: Gap junctions form a cytoplasmic “tunnel” for diffusion of small molecules (<1000 Da) between two neighbouring cells
Gap junctions are formed by proteins called connexons
Connexons in the membrane of one cell are lined up with connexons of a neighbouring cell to form dodecameric gap junctions

questions.text: All of the following are true about gap junctions except-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Gap junctions form chemical synapses
Gap junctions form electrical synapses. They for a low resistance path for bi-directional movement of ions, molecules, sugars and amino acids less than 1000 Daltons.

choices.text: Upstroke of the smooth muscle action potential
Plateau phase of the ventricular muscle action potential
Downstroke of the skeletal muscle action potential

questions.text: All except the following are associated with increase in calcium conductance -
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Downstroke of the skeletal muscle action potential
Downstroke of the skeletal muscle action potential is due to opening of voltage gated potassium channels and an increase in potassium conductance.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with severe migraine headaches that are accompanied by hemiparesis. Genetic analysis confirms the suspicion of an inherited channelopathy. The membrane potential will depolarize by the greatest amount if the membrane permeability increases for which of the following ions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Sodium
Increasing the membrane permeability for sodium will cause an inward movement of sodium. Gain of positive charge causes the membrane to depolarize. Increasing permeability for potassium or chloride will cause the membrane to hyperpolarize.

choices.text: Conduction velocity of its action potential

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics of an axon is most dependent on myelination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Conduction velocity of its action potential
Velocity of conduction of a nerve impulse depends on its diameter and presence of myelin.

questions.text: Which of the following organs has the highest arterio-venous oxygen differences under normal conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

heart
Heart has a very high oxygen demand at rest. Because of the high rate of metabolism in the heart compared with its blood flow, it has the highest arterio-venous oxygen difference under normal conditions. The heart can extract a large amount of oxygen because of its high capillary density.

questions.text: A patient has an oxygen consumption of 240mL/min. His systemic arterial oxygen concentration is 180mL/L of blood, and his pulmonary artery concentration is 160mL/L of blood. What is his cardiac output?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

12L/min Cardiac output by the Fick’s principle C.O. = oxygen consumption per minute/ (arterio-venous oxygen difference in mL/L) = 240mL/min/ (180 – 160)mL/min = 240/20 L/min = 12L/min

choices.text: Net fluid reabsorption into pulmonary capillaries

questions.text: A patient with MI develops progressive dyspnea and hypoxemia suggestive of cardiogenic shock. She is transferred to the ICU and a Swan-Ganz catheter is inserted. The patient is found to have a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 25 mm Hg, which is indicative of a decrease in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Net fluid reabsorption into pulmonary capillaries
Normal pulmonary capillary wedge pressure is 8-12 mm Hg. PCWP is also an index of pressures in the left atrium and in the LV at the end of diastole; that is, PCWP is an index of left ventricular preload.
PCWP of 25 mm Hg is indicative of left heart failure. Elevated PCWP will increase pulmonary capillary hydrostatic pressure driving fluid out of the pulmonary capillaries and decreasing net reabsorption of fluid into the capillaries.

choices.text: V/Q ratio of the alveolus equals zero
Po2 of the alveolus will be equal to that in the inspired air
Po2 of the alveolus will be equal to the mixed venous Po2
Increase in shunting in the lung

questions.text: Which of the following will occur if blood flow to an alveolus is totally obstructed by a pulmonary thromboembolism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Po2 of the alveolus will be equal to that in the inspired air
Pulmonary thromboembolism will result in areas of the lung that are ventilated but not perfused, yielding a V/Q ratio equal to infinity and an increase in alveolar and total dead space. The composition of air in the affected alveoli will be equal to the humidified inspired air.

questions.text: A 80-year-old woman resents with polyuria and polydipsia. Blood analysis reveals hypernatremia, and urinalysis shows hypotonicity with increased free water clearance. In which of the following conditions is an increased free water clearance a hallmark of the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

diabetes insipidus
In Diabetes insipidus, lack of ADH causes excretion of large volumes of extremely dilute urine, increasing the free water clearance.

choices.text: He loses voluntary control over his respiration
Central chemoreceptors will no longer be able to exert any control over the ventilation
Involuntary control over respiration will be lost but voluntary control will be present

questions.text: A 38-year-old male is brought to the Emergency after being thrown from his motorcycle following a collision with a stationary trolley. It is determined that he has a brain transection above the pons. How will this lesion affect the control of breathing in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

He loses voluntary control over his respiration 
Transection of the brain stem above the pons will prevent any voluntary changes in ventilation by cutting the pathways from the higher centres.

questions.text: A 16-year-old adolescent boy is being treated with the macrolide antibiotic erythromycin complains of nausea, intestinal cramping, and diarrhoea. The side effects are the result of the antibiotic binding to receptors in the GI tract that recognize which gastrointestinal hormone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

motilin
Erythromycin group of drugs bind to motilin-like receptors in the GI tract. Motilin stimulates increased contractions by a direct action on smooth muscle and by activation of excitatory enteric nerves. This results in increased intestinal motility, abdominal cramping and diarrhoea.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the Emergency with shortness of breath. His OHDC was shifted from that for normal haemoglobin A depicted in the curve A in the figure given below to curve B. this finding is consistent with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Recent transfusion with banked blood
In banked blood, glycolysis is inhibited which decreases the 2,3-BPG, shifting the OHDC to the left.

questions.text:
The following figure shows a forced expiration for a healthy person and a patient complaining of shortness of breath.    

The patient most likely has which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Emphysema In the patient the FVC is reduced. FEV1 which is the forcefully expired volume of air in one second is also reduced. However, the FEV1/FVC ratio in the patient is markedly reduced. A marked reduction in FEV1/FVC ratio is typically seen in obstructive lung disease, such as emphysema. FEV1/ FVC ratio will also be decreased in old age. However, marked reduction such as seen in the figure points towards emphysema. In restrictive lung disease, FEV1/FVC ratios is normal to increased. In these asbestosis and other diseases characterized by interstitial fibrosis the radial traction on the airways is increased. That is, the airways are held open to a greater extent at any given lung volume, reducing their resistance to airflow.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy with weakness affecting the proximal muscles is found to have a mutation of a gene that encodes for the protein dystrophin. Genetic alteration in dystrophin lead to progressive muscle weakness because dystrophin provides structural support to the sarcolemma by binding with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Actin to β- dystroglycan
The large dystrophin molecule (molecular weight 427,000) is a rod-like protein that connects the thin actin filaments to the transmembrane protein β-dystroglycan in the sarcolemma. 
Duchenne muscular dystrophy is a serious form of dystrophy in which dystrophin is absent from muscle. It is X-linked and usually fatal by age 30. In a milder form of the disease, Becker muscular dystrophy, dustrophin is present but absent or reduced in amount.

choices.text: Binding of O2 to hemoglobin in lungs drives release of CO2 from haemoglobin
The sum of the partial pressures of CO2 and O2 cannot exceed a known threshold in blood
High partial pressure of CO2 in tissues facilitates O2 unloading in peripheral tissues
High partial pressure of CO2 in tissues causes alkalemia, which is necessary for O2 unloading

questions.text: A research scientist attempts to understand the influence of carbon dioxide content in blood on its oxygen binding. The scientist adds carbon dioxide to dog blood and measures the uptake of oxygen in the blood versus oxygen pressure in the peripheral tissue. He notes in one dog that with the addition of carbon dioxide with a pressure of 90 mmHg, the oxygen pressure in the peripheral tissue rose from 26 to 33 mmHg. How can this phenomenon be explained?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Bohr effect is seen with increase in PCO2 more O2 is released to the tissues ie. It causes right shift of the curve.

choices.text: Dominance of the excitatory reticulospinal pathway leading to rigidity of extensors in lower limbs
Rubrospinal excitation of flexors of upper limbs
Spasticity is due to facilitation of the gamma loop
Spasticity is due to inhibition of gamma loop

questions.text: A 61-year-old man had a cardiac arrest on the golf course. Almost 8 minutes of resuscitation, normal sinus rhythm with a blood pressure of 110/75 mm Hg is obtained. His neurologic examination done in the hospital one hour after the cardiac arrest reveals decorticate posturing and no eye opening in response to pain. The pupils are reactive. Oculocephalic and corneal reflexes are present but reduced bilaterally. All of the following are the physiological bases of decorticate posturing except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Spasticity is due to inhibition of gamma loop.  Decortication is characterized by flexion of upper limbs and extension of lower limbs (“mummy posturing”). The flexion in upper limbs is explained by rubrospinal excitation of flexor muscled in the upper limbs. Hyperextension of the lower limbs is due to dominance of the excitatory reticulospinal pathway, which in turn indirectly activate the αmotor neurons (via Ia spindle afferent activity) which is called the gamma loop.

questions.text: After secretion of trypsinogen into the duodenum, the enzyme is converted into its active form, trypsin, by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Enteropeptidase
Enteropeptidase or enterokinase converts trypsinogen into its active form- trypsin Trypsin in turn will inactivate all inactive pancreatic proteolytic enzymes to their active form.

questions.text:
A medical student is studying the fluid exchange in skeletal muscle capillaries in a laboratory animal. He determines that fluid is being filtered out of the capillaries with a net filtration pressure of 10mmHg. He obtains the following values – 

Capillary hydrostatic pressure is 45mmHg

Capillary oncotic pressure is 25 mmHg

Interstitial oncotic pressure is 10mmHg

Which of the following is the interstitial hydrostatic pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Starling forces govern the rate of filtration across capillaries. It depends on four pressures – capillary hydrostatic pressure, capillary oncotic pressure, interstitial hydrostatic pressure and interstitial oncotic pressure.

So, NFP= PCap + πIF – PIF – πcap .  From the above data, 

10= 45+ 10 – 25 + πIF   = 30 + πIF , hence πIF= 20mmHg.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy playing in his garden accidentally steps on a broken bottle with his bare right foot. His right leg immediately lifts up while his left leg extends even before he cries out in pain. Which of the following best describes the type of reflex and the centre involved in this reflex?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

polysynaptic; spinal- This is an example of crossed extensor reflex elicited by a painful stimulus. Crossed extensor is a polysynaptic and spinal reflex.

questions.text: The body fluid volume changes in a 34 year old patient are shown below in Darrow-Yannet diagram (solid line – normal, dotted line – patient). Which of the following is the cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Darrow Yannet diagram depicts in this case that osmolarity has increased and ECF volume has decreased – this can happen only in loss of hypotonic fluid – which occurs in diabetes insipidus – less ADH or failure of action of ADH – leading to decreased reabsorption of water in the collecting ducts.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man, victim of road traffic accident is brought to the Emergency and is diagnosed with hemi section of the left side of the spinal cord at C6. Which of the following function is likely to be lost in the right leg of this man?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pain and temperature

This is a patient of Brown Sequard syndrome. Pain and temperature will be lost on the opposite side below the level of lesion.

questions.text: Synaptic transmission between the pain fibres from the viscera in the pelvis to spinal cord neurons is mediated by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Substance P

The neurotransmitter secreted by C fibres for visceral pain is substance P.
